Fletcher's twin sons, Jack and Tyler, defected from the Manchester City academy to United's in 2023 but they are now ineligible to feature for the under 18s, which partly influenced their father's decision to take charge.
Fletcher took a back seat as Jack and Tyler mulled over their futures two years ago and which national side to represent. Jack chose England and Tyler is a Scotland youth international.

Sir Alex Ferguson had recommended Fletcher to replace Nick Cox as the director of academy but Fletcher's long-term ambition is to become a first team manager. This move should strengthen his CV. Kieran McKenna, now Ipswich Town manager, was the United U18 coach before Jose Mourinho promoted him to the first team dugout in 2016.

Fletcher is due to work closely with Travis Binnion, the head of player development and coaching who oversees the under 21s. United have also allocated Fletcher a key leadership role in the academy that will oversee all of the age groups.
United maintain the priority with academy talents will be player development and not results.

headline: Man United transfer news LIVE - Viktor Gyokeres deal, Bryan Mbeumo latest, Emi Martinez boost
body: Hello and welcome back to the Manchester United transfer blog on Monday, July 14.

We are now less than a week out from United returning to the pitch as they seek to put right the wrongs from last season in the Premier League. As we edge ever closer to the serious stuff beginning in mid-August, United will be hoping to complete some more business in the next couple of weeks to stand them in better stead.

Sporting's Viktor Gyokeres has been heavily linked with a move to United this summer but that opportunity had looked to be fizzling out when Arsenal increased their interest. However, negotiations have hit a wall with United potentially in a position to capitalise.

Andre Onana's hamstring injury has thrust the goalkeeper conversation back to the forefront this weekend. Botafogo's John Victor has been named as a potential target for the Reds to strengthen that position.

Finally, overarching all of this is the talk surrounding Bryan Mbeumo and the continued negotiations with Brentford. As of yet, the Reds have still been unable to reach an agreement with the Bees over his signature.
Keep across all this and more from United in our dedicated blog below...
Reports in Brazil have claimed that Man United are 'preparing an offer' of £26million for Richard Rios this summer.
Palmeiras Online have claimed that a bid could be incoming from the Reds following the Colombian's impressive performances at the Club World Cup.
£26m is understood to be a value that Palmeiras want.
Darren Fletcher has been appointed to a new role at Manchester United.
Fletcher is now the lead coach of United's Under-18s, having succeeded Adam Lawrence in the role at Old Trafford.
"I am really excited to take on this new role and increase my responsibility to directly develop our young players," Fletcher told United's club website.
"I'm looking forward to working with such a talented age-group; supporting them to reach their potential and preparing them to enjoy careers at the highest level possible."
Amid ongoing speculation around their future, Marcus Rashford and Alejandro Garnacho both training together at Carrington last week.
Both players could leave Manchester United this summer as Ruben Amorim continues his squad rebuild ahead of his first full season as the club's head coach.
Rashford and Garnacho did not train alongside their United teammates, with moves away from Old Trafford becoming increasingly likely as the days go on.
MORE HERE.
The summer transfer window is still open and Manchester United are being linked with several potential new signings.
There are also some members of the United squad who are being linked with moves away from Old Trafford.
MORE HERE.
There has been an update on Alejandro Garnacho's future at Manchester United.
Garnacho has been heavily linked with a move away from United this summer and is not expected to be part of the club's travelling squad for the pre-season tour of the United States.
MORE HERE.
Manchester United may be about to be handed a boost amid reported interest in Aston Villa striker Ollie Watkins.
United have been credited with an interest in signing Watkins in recent weeks, and it seems that Villa are looking to sign a striker of their own.
There have been reports in Portugal claiming that Villa have identified a centre forward they are looking to sign with a view to being a replacement for Watkins.
MORE HERE.
Viktor Gyokeres has been heavily linked with a move to Manchester United this summer, but the chances of a potential transfer appear to be almost impossible now.
Reports on Sunday emerged claiming that Arsenal had reached an agreement to sign Gyokeres this summer in a deal worth up to €73.5m (£63.7m) including add-ons.
United are still being linked with signing a striker but it now remains to be seen where the club will turn as the transfer window rolls on.
Greetings and welcome to the latest LIVE Manchester United transfer blog.
United are still working on a deal to sign Bryan Mbeumo, while a fresh update has emerged about the future of Viktor Gyokeres.
We'll be on hand to provide the latest United transfer news, rumours and gossip that may emerge from Old Trafford throughout the day.
Make sure you stay tuned!
Join us tomorrow for more Manchester United transfer news.
We'll have you covered ahead of United's first pre-season friendly on Saturday.
Manchester United look set to miss out on Viktor Gyokeres this summer following news that Arsenal have finally reached an agreement with Sporting CP.

After agreeing a five-year contract with Gyokeres and his camp, the north Londoners now look to have finally agreed a deal with Sporting CP to get their man. The Athletic have reported that Arsenal are now taking the final steps in negotiations with the Portuguese champions and are processing to get the deal done.
Reports in Italy have claimed that Jadon Sancho has an agreement in principle with Juventus.

Tuttosport have claimed that Man United and the Serie A side remain in talks after Sanco agreed a four-year deal in Turin worth over €5million per season. The deal includes an option for a further year.
Atalanta defender Giorgio Scalvini has been strongly linked with a move to the Premier League this summer.
Newcastle and Tottenham said said to be keen but according to The i Paper has suggested that Man United are showing interest in the highly-talented centre-back.
Atalanta want more than £50m for the defender and are hoping to tie Scalvini down to a new contract.
Man United have made 'initial enquiries' into signing Bayern Munich and Portugal midfielder Joao Palhinha this summer.
A report by Caught Offside has claimed that United are 'maintaining communication' with Bayern this summer with Palhinha's future at the club unclear.
The report states that Bayern would demand between £25million and £30million, a lower fee to the one he signed for the club a year ago.
Manchester United have been told to complete the signing of Dusan Vlahovic this summer ''immediately'.
Former Juve striker Darko Kovacevic has insisted he should seek pastures new with haste, and given talk around a move to the Premier League, his wish may come true.
"I’d say to Dušan to move on immediately," the 51-year-old told Gazzetta dello Sport.

"It’s not easy to leave Juventus, I say this from personal experience, but sometimes you have to get back in the game to get back to being happy and at the top. Someone like Vlahović must always be a starter, at Juventus or elsewhere."
United's nutritional department has received a significant shake-up.

Omar Meziane left his position as first-team head chef in December to join McLaren's Formula One team, and Thomas Maynard left his role as first-team performance nutritionist at the end of last season.
The department is now essentially brand new after the appointments of Will Carvalho (head performance chef), Marcus Hannon (head of sports nutrition) and Filipe Sousa (first-team nutritionist).
MORE HERE.
According to Fabrizio Romano, the structure of United's add-ons for Mbeumo is currently obstructing a deal being agreed.
It is understood that while a £62.5m total fee was being offered, the Bees were unhappy about the manner of the £7.5m add-ons.
The Brentford camp are believed to be feeling like those add-ons are too difficult to achieve and they need those to be more realistic before they agree to sell their talisman.
It is looking like United are going to be clearing house of their goalkeepers this summer with Radek Vitek the latest to be linked with a move away.
The Sun understands Championship club Millwall are interested on the 21-year-old who has just left Austrian side BW Linz after a season-long loan spell.
However, United's young shot stopper is not the only player of interest for Millwall with veteran goalkeeper Tim Krul and Everton's Joao Virginia both thought to be of interest.
According to The Mirror, Altay Bayindir's agent is in Manchester to discuss his client's future.
The meeting comes amid talk that United are interested in signing a new goalkeeper, in particular John from Botafogo.
Bayindir reportedly rejected offers from Europe in January and new approaches have been building in recent weeks for his services.
A move for the 29-year-old would be considered a risk after he has only featured once in Europe - a short loan spell at Real Valladolid in the 2023/24 season.
Since moving to Botafogo in January 2024, John has managed to become a regular for the Brazilian club.
He played for them in the Club World Cup this summer, notably keeping a clean sheet in the group stages against European champions PSG.
According to Goal Brasil, Botafogo are preparing for the departure of their goalkeeper John Victor in the summer transfer window.
It is claimed that in light of Onana's injury, United have submitted an offer for the shot stopper.
Onana has suffered a hamstring injury and will be in a race against the clock to be fit again for the start of the Premier League season against Arsenal.
As they look to continue strengthening for the future, MEN Sport understands that United want to complete the signings of England U17s captain Seth Ridgeon and Tyrese Noubissie.
Ridgeon is currently on the books of Fulham while Noubissie is expected to leave Manchester City's academy this summer.
United have already sealed the signing of Harley Emsden-James, 16, from Southampton this summer.
MORE HERE.
According to The Mirror, Rashford is set to hold talks with United this coming week to discuss his future.
The forward is thought to be in limbo after being informed that he is not in manager Amorim's plans.
However, his current wage is proving a stumbling block to allowing him to depart with a loan move now considered to be the most likely option for him.
Earlier today we brought you reports that Garnacho had rejected Al Nassr this summer.
Now, it appears that Rashford has also rejected a lucrative approach from Saudi Arabia.
Mundo Deportivo understands that Rashford is uninterested in moving to the unnamed Saudi Pro League club with his focus remaining on a move to Barcelona.
Well, there is still a chance that United can benefit from Arsenal stalling in negotiations.
Journalist Ben Jacobs told The United Stand recently that he remains open to an Old Trafford move.
The facts as he sees them are that Gyokeres invited interest from Arsenal and never explicitly stated that he did not want to sign for United.
So if United can somehow stump up the asking price for Gyokeres, that deal could be back on.
Amidst all of this, Gyokeres has declared his desire to be playing Premier League football in the 2025/26 season.
Speaking to L'Equipe, the Swede said:

Maybe [I will leave]. That’s football, you never know. I don’t think about it; we’ll see what happens. If something happens, it will. The most important thing for me is to play for a club that really wants me. It’s one of the biggest leagues (Premier League) in Europe. I spent several years there without being able to play a single match. So, of course, it’s something I’d like to do. It would be great revenge.
According to the Daily Telegraph, Garnacho has rejected the chance to sign permanently for Al Nassr this summer.
It is believed that Ronaldo's team tried to persuade the Argentine to join them for their Saudi Pro League title pursuit.
However, Garnacho's aim is to stay in the Premier League and is unwilling to move to the Middle East at this stage.
There is a clear reason behind that, and it all stems from the valuation Sporting have for Gyokeres.
The Swede was under the impression that should a bid of £52m plus £8.67m in add-ons was to be submitted, he would be allowed to leave the Lisbon club.
While Varandas agrees that holding out for his £85m release clause would not be possible, he is also unwilling to let the striker leave for that little.
It is believed that Sporting's asking price is £60.67m plus £8.67m in add-ons and, as of yet, no club has reached that valuation.
In the latest twist in the Gyokeres saga, the striker has been issued with disciplinary action from Sporting after failing to arrive for pre-season training.
Sporting president Frederico Varandas sent a clear message to the striker on Saturday:

We're calm. Everything can be solved with the closure of the market, a hefty fine and an apology to the group. If they don't want to pay Viktor's fair market value, we'll be very comfortable with that for the next three years. If the geniuses who are devising this strategy think that this puts pressure on me to make it easier for him to leave, not only are they completely wrong, but they are also making it more complicated for the player to leave. No one is above the interests of the club. Whoever they are.
Hello and welcome back to the United transfer blog this Sunday morning.
My name is Jack Flintham and I shall be keeping you across the latest United news throughout the morning.
Temperatures may be soaring outside and the transfer window drama surrounding this man is certainly heating up too...

headline: Manchester United transfer state of play: Bryan Mbeumo negotiations, striker search & slow sales
body: After announcing they had reached an agreement with Wolves to sign Matheus Cunha on the opening day of the transfer window last month, Manchester United finalised the deal just 11 days later.

It was United's way of laying down an early marker and confirming they meant business this summer. In between triggering Cunha's £62.5million release clause and unveiling him as their first summer signing, they also tabled their opening offer for Brentford ace Bryan Mbeumo.

United saw their opening offer of £55m turned down for the Cameroon international, but a second bid, understood to be in excess of £60m, looked as though it would be enough to lure him to Old Trafford.

However, despite this publication confirming a deal was close almost three weeks ago, negotiations between United and Brentford remain ongoing. Both the Reds and the attacker are equally keen to get a deal over the line.

With just over a week to go until the squad will fly to the United States for their pre-season tour, United are in a race against time to ensure Mbeumo gets a place on the plane. New signings have linked up with the squad mid-tour before, such as Andre Onana two years ago, but it would be ideal to have Mbeumo in place beforehand.

United have rightly prioritised attacking signings this summer and the addition of Cunha, who scored 17 goals across all competitions last season, marked an excellent start. However, the Brazilian's addition to the squad so early in the window immediately raised the benchmark.
Having been in discussions with Brentford for more than a month, some United fans are becoming frustrated. Some are even suggesting the club should abandon their pursuit.

In addition to wanting to sign Mbeumo, United are also prioritising the addition of a striker this summer. Liam Delap was earmarked as a top target ahead of the window opening on June 1 because of the £30m release clause in his Ipswich Town contract.

As big a risk as it was to try and sign another relatively raw and unproven striker, his release clause meant he was an attainable option. However, Chelsea were more appealing to Delap and he moved to Stamford Bridge.

United continue to be linked with strikers both domestically and abroad, whether they be attached to clubs or free agents, but no concrete bids are understood to have been submitted. It is likely this particular search will go deep into the window.

As far as outgoings are concerned, it is no secret by now Tyrell Malacia, Marcus Rashford, Alejandro Garnacho, Jadon Sancho and Antony have informed the club they want to leave. They are not training with the rest of the squad at Carrington and United are equally keen to offload them.

However, offers have not been forthcoming thus far, meaning United are not understood to be close to saying farewell to any of them. Rashford's and Sancho's wages could be problematic for prospective suitors, particularly in Rashford's case, meaning his most likely exit route could be via a loan deal.
Rashford, who is valued at £40m, wants to move to a club that can offer him Champions League football. Barcelona and Bayern Munich continue to be linked with him.

Real Betis, meanwhile, are continuing to express interest in Antony after his successful loan spell in Seville in the second half of last season, but they are yet to come up with a formal offer. United need to sell him for £32.58m to avoid a loss under the profit and sustainability rules (PSR).

headline: RAILSTON: Manchester United secure future of exciting defender with contract offer
body: Manchester United youngster Godwill Kukonki is set to sign his first professional contract.
Kukonki was named in a first-team squad for the first time against Arsenal on December 4, and Ruben Amorim said the youngster had "impressed" him and his maturity was noticeable.
The highly rated left-footed centre-back was named in United's post-season tour travelling squad in May and he made appearances from the bench against ASEAN All-Stars and Hong Kong.

When Amorim oversaw his first training session at Carrington in November after his appointment from Sporting Lisbon, Kukonki made a strong impression and travelled to Portman Road for Amorim's first game against Ipswich Town.
He was subsequently named on the bench at the Emirates. Kukonki continued to be around the first-team and made the squad for both legs against Lyon in the Europa League quarter-finals.
He has been rewarded with his first professional deal and has been tipped for a bright future.
There have been early comparisons made between the exciting Kukonki and Manchester City defender Josko Gvardiol and he is a unique option because he is a left-footed defender.
Kukonki already stands at a towering 6ft 5ins and his physicality should help him as he pushes toward a debut, which is his ultimate aim after making progress through the youth ranks.
The Stoke-on-Trent-born lad can also play at left-back and has represented England's Under-17s.

headline: Manchester United confirm new job for Darren Fletcher
body: Manchester United have appointed former midfielder Darren Fletcher as the Under-18s' new lead coach.
The Scot, who returned to Old Trafford in a coaching capacity four years ago, has succeeded Adam Lawrence, who left the club earlier this summer to pursue a fresh challenge elsewhere.

United have confirmed Fletcher, 41, has immediately stepped into the breach and will oversee the Under-18s' pre-season preparations. He has already overseen a training camp at the Adidas global headquarters in Germany as well as an 8-2 win over QPR at Carrington at the weekend.
On being installed as the Under-18s' new boss, Fletcher told United's club website: "I am really excited to take on this new role and increase my responsibility to directly develop our young players.
"I'm looking forward to working with such a talented age-group; supporting them to reach their potential and preparing them to enjoy careers at the highest level possible."

Fletcher, who made more than 340 appearances for United during his playing career, will have ambitions of maintaining the excellent standards that have been set at Under-18s level in recent years. Lawrence oversaw a successful period for the Under-18s during a two-year stint in charge. He led them to three trophies in 2023/24 and the semi-finals of the FA Youth Cup last season.
Explaining what Fletcher will bring to the role, United director of football Jason Wilcox said: "We are delighted that Darren will lead our Under-18s group.
"He knows exactly what it takes to be a successful academy graduate and has played a key role in shaping the pathway for so many of our young players in recent years.

"Darren's excellent relationships across the entire staff will only increase the strong connection between the academy and first-team, further enhancing our ability to produce world-class players ready to excel at Manchester United."

headline: Latest Manchester United signing shares farewell message ahead of finalising transfer
body: Southampton defender Harley Emsden-James has paid an emotional farewell to the Championship club ahead of his move to Manchester United being officially announced.
The talented 16-year-old is understood to have finalised a move to Old Trafford after becoming the latest youngster to catch the club's eye.

Director of football Jason Wilcox, who worked at St Mary's prior to moving to United, is understood to have played a key role in the deal. Southampton will secure a compensation package for the teenager.

Under Ineos' stewardship, United have developed a reputation signing young talent in low-risk, high-reward deals. They have already maintained that approach this summer by recently securing the signing of young striker Enzo Kana-Biyik from French club Le Havre.

Although United are yet to officially confirm the arrival of Emsden-James, his latest social media post, in which he has thanked everyone associated with Southampton for helping him in his career so far, suggests it is only a matter of time before he is unveiled as the club's latest recruit.

He posted on Instagram: "After nine unforgettable years at Southampton FC, my time with the club has come to an end. I'm incredibly grateful for all the memories made and the amazing people I've met throughout my journey.
"A huge thank you to all the staff who have supported and guided me over the years, to my teammates who've become friends, and to everyone who's been a part of this chapter with me.
"Southampton will always hold a special place in my heart. Onto the next chapter!"
Emsden-James, who will turn 17 next March, will link up with United's academy and attempt to take his career to the next level.

headline: 'Now or never' - former Manchester United star sends bold warning to Ruben Amorim
body: Former Manchester United ace Ashley Young has said it is "now or never" for Ruben Amorim to make his mark at Old Trafford.

The Portuguese head coach was appointed United boss last November and was unable to make the immediate impact he would have dreamt of in M16, leading his side to a 15th-placed finish in the Premier League.

This summer's transfer window is key to that ambition and United have made a relatively slow start to proceedings, overseeing just one statement signing so far. It is hoped the situation will improve as the summer continues to unfold.
But in the opinion of Young, who spent nine years at Old Trafford, Amorim has got to hit the ground running at the start of the new campaign come what may.
"We saw that he didn't want to come in at the time that he did; he wanted to be in at the start of the season. It was going to be tough either way when you come in halfway through a season.
"I am sure any manager would say it's a tough ask. And when you're joining the biggest club in the world, and where they were at, it was going to be even harder.
"I think it has been said that you are going to have to give him time; he needs time and how many transfer windows? Who knows.
"You have got to set your marker, put your stamp down, as soon as you start this season. I don't think that anyone can give him anymore excuses.

"It is now or never, really, to be honest. He has got to have a good pre-season with the team, work out what his team is, what his best team is, what players fit into the system, unless he is going to change the system, but you can't see him changing the formation that he has been playing.
"It is going to be intriguing to see what happens after this pre-season."

headline: 'What Ruben likes' - Bryan Mbuemo coach backs dream Manchester United partnership
body: Bryan Mbuemo is exactly the sort of player Ruben Amorim wants at Manchester United, according to his former coach. The United manager is looking to make Mbuemo his second major signing of the summer after Wolves forward Matheus Cunha, with negotiations for the Brentford star ongoing.

United know what they are getting in a proven Premier League talent and Mbuemo may see similarities in Amorim to the coach he had back at the beginning of his playing career. Rui Almeida trained him when he was a teenager coming through the youth team at Troyes in France's second division.
The 19-year-old would last only a year there before Brentford snapped him up in the Championship, and Almeida did not need long to see the qualities that would stand Mbuemo out among teammates.
Manchester United have launched their new home kit for the 2025/26 season with an Adidas shirt paying tribute to Old Trafford.
Fans can order their Men's, Women's and Kid's shirt today.

"In my opinion, he had two or three things to stand out - his physical capacities but also he thought really fast - before the ball arrived to him he already had two options in his mind. From a young age, we told him that each training had to be like a final and he caught that and got that for his life.
"He trained like every session was really important. That maybe separated him and took him to another level from other talents that we had at his age.

"His decision-making in high pressure was really different and we saw that. After that, he was fast and dribbled and his shooting was very good also but at the time we told him, Bryan you always play right winger because he had a great left foot but I told him the challenge if he wanted to improve was to learn to play in the other positions.
"We put him as a second striker and a a striker and from there he has done so well at Brentford. If Ruben takes him, he will play all the sides of the 3-4-3."

Almeida has had a varied coaching career, as may be expected for somebody who began at just 26. A few years in his native Portugal were followed by seven in France before jobs further afield in Algeria, Saudi Arabia and most recently Morocco.
He is six months into life at Difaa El Jadidi, and enjoying life in a country that is only growing interest in football ahead of hosting the 2030 World Cup.

"I like the experience of the last six months and they invited me to stay," he said. "With the World Cup coming, they are improving a lot of things. The league is very competitive, Morocco came third at the last World Cup even if many of the players are in different leagues like many countries, but recently the level is increasing. This year they will start eight new stadiums in the league so the facilities are improving."

Almeida has always kept an eye out for the players he has coached along the way though, and has been thrilled to see how well Mbuemo has done in the Premier League. As United close in on a move, Almeida believes they will be signing a player who can combine well with Cunha as well as do the teamwork that is crucial to Amorim's ethos.

"Manchester United fans have been waiting for a title again for a long time so there will be pressure, and Bryan will need the team behind him to help him but he will also help the team to do good things. One thing that you always need and I see Bryan doing at Brentford is he is a team player.
"He's very good individually but he works a lot for the team, he runs a lot for the team and defends a lot for the team so I think he is a player that Ruben likes a lot.
"I also think he's a good complement for Cunha. Sometimes in teams you need good complement for players. They are different players and teams need that difference in the forwards."

headline: Mbeumo delay, squad strength truth, concerns grow - Manchester United transfer window verdict so far
body: Manchester United's summer transfer window could be one of the most important in the club's recent history.
Ruben Amorim will take charge of pre-season for the first time as United manager as he prepares for his first full season in charge.

The jury remains out on his position as manager after a difficult start to life in the Old Trafford dugout and after a lot of trust was placed in him ahead of the 2025/26 season, United have to have a strong transfer window.
United have so far sealed the £62.5million signing of Matheus Cunha from Wolves, as well as teenagers Diego Leon and Enzo Kaya-Biyik, but are yet to sell and of their wantaway players.
They have also seen two bids rejected for Brentford star Bryan Mbeumo as they look to agree a deal with the Bees to sign the 25-year-old, who scored 20 Premier League goals last season.
Cunha has been added to the squad, but Alejandro Garnacho and Marcus Rashford were at Amorim's disposal when he was appointed and they're not part of his plans for the new season.

Antony and Tyrell Malacia were also at Amorim's disposal before leaving on loan to Real Betis and PSV respectively in the January window. Their returns to Carrington have been delayed as they look for new clubs.
United finished 15th in the Premier League and, yet, they have a weaker squad in the third week of July than at the end of last season, which must concern Amorim behind closed doors.
Simply put, United need to get a move on in the summer transfer window because they're close to letting Amorim down.

There has been no breakthrough in negotiations with Brentford for Bryan Mbeumo and it's hoped he'll be on the plane to the USA. Another signing would be ideal by then to give Amorim time to work with his new additions, although sales are required to unlock funds for further incomings.
Selling is just as important as buying in the transfer window and serious concerns will be raised if one of the five castaways (Garnacho, Rashford, Sancho, Antony and Malacia) aren't sold soon.

After wrapping up the signing of Cunha so early on in the window, United would have hoped to have achieved more by now. Cunha had not officially finalised his move to Old Trafford by the time they submitted their opening offer for Mbeumo, highlighting just how keen they were to get their business done nice and early.

It would have been unrealistic to suggest United could have got everything done by now, especially when sales are so important this summer, but they would have hoped for more than just Cunha and Diego Leon.

With the start of the pre-season tour now less than a fortnight away, supporters are within their rights to feel slightly concerned. United finished 15th last term and desperately need to add fresh blood to Amorim's squad.

The longer this current lull persists, the more restless supporters will become. However, if United get a deal over the line for Mbeumo before too long and go on to secure the services of a striker, all should be forgiven.
The signing of Matheus Cunha so early in the transfer window was an excellent start to United's summer business but since then everything has gone a bit stale.
The wait for Bryan Mbeumo continues to lumber on and the longer that wait continues the more frustration will grow among supporters.

United need to sell players to buy beyond Mbeumo too and while elite forwards continue to fall off the market, the delay in offloading the likes of Marcus Rashford, Jadon Sancho, Alejandro Garnacho, Antony and Tyrell Malacia becomes more damaging.
Something needs to give this week and United need to make progress on a signing or a sale to kickstart their business before Saturday's opening pre-season friendly against Leeds United.

headline: RAILSTON: Manchester United confirm injury blow ahead of USA pre-season tour
body: Manchester United goalkeeper Andre Onana has suffered a hamstring injury after reporting for pre-season.
Onana has responded well to initial treatment and will travel to the USA this month with the squad, but his participation in the Premier League Summer Series has been thrown in doubt.
United will travel across the Atlantic to face West Ham, Bournemouth and Everton in the States. Onana's injury means Altay Bayindir could be the first-choice goalkeeper during the three-game tour.
Onana's future at Old Trafford became a talking point last season and it remains to be seen whether Ruben Amorim now believes it's necessary to sign a new goalkeeper in the summer window.
Onana had been preparing under the assumption he will still be at United for 2025/2026.
The Cameroon international made an impressive start to last season, but his form plummeted and he made high-profile mistakes against Nottingham Forest, Viktoria Plzen and Lyon.
Although Bayindir made 10 appearances last season as Amorim granted him more opportunities, he conceded 18 goals and failed to convince as a second-choice goalkeeper option.
Tom Heaton is the third-choice goalkeeper and recently signed a one-year contract extension.

headline: Player agent 'flies in' for Man United transfer talks as summer move could be sealed
body: Manchester United's back-up goalkeeper Altay Bayindir is reportedly set to welcome his agent to the city this week for talks surrounding his future at the club.

Bayindir arrived at Old Trafford in the summer of 2023 as United's then manager Erik ten Hag looked for a back-up to first choice Andre Onana. In his first season in Manchester, the Turkish shot stopper made just one appearance against Newport County in the FA Cup as Ten Hag was reluctant to swap out the Cameroonian.

Last season, with Onana's form still shaky and Ten Hag removed from power, Bayindir was given a few more opportunities to impress. However, his performances were inconsistent albeit his performance against Arsenal in the FA Cup in January was impressive.

Despite Ruben Amorim being more confident to trust Bayindir, he remained firmly a second choice and now even that position is in doubt. The Mirror reported on Sunday that United are interested in signing another goalkeeper this summer with Botafogo's John thought to be high on their shortlist.

If he was to arrive, Bayindir's position at Old Trafford would start to look even more uncertain. MEN Sport understands Onana has received reassurances from the United backroom staff that he remains part of the plans and Tom Heaton signed a new contract to be third choice.

As such, The Mirror reports that Bayindir's agent Sefa Seyrek has flown to Manchester to discuss his client's position at the club. It is believed that the 27-year-old fended off interest from Europe for his signature in January as he did not want to leave.
In recent weeks, that interest has resurfaced again and Bayindir could, this time, welcome such an approach.

headline: Manchester United need two transfers to confirm vital agreement for Bryan Mbeumo transfer
body: Manchester United are still looking to complete a deal for Brentford star Bryan Mbeumo as their next summer signing.

United have already added Matheus Cunha to their ranks this summer in a £62.5million deal from Wolves. Now it seems that Mbeumo is the next target that United will be looking to bring to Old Trafford ahead of Ruben Amorim's first full season as the new head coach.

There is still plenty of time left for United to complete their transfer business, with the summer transfer window closing on September 1. However, there have been some concerns over the last couple of weeks about the potential delay in reaching an agreement to sign Mbeumo.

United have had two bids rejected by Brentford for Mbeumo, with the second believed to be worth more than £60million with add-ons. United are still confident that a deal can be agreed with Brentford, and now a fresh update has emerged on a separate deal that may affect the chances of the Cameroon international moving to Old Trafford.

The report goes on to say that Juventus would need to sell two wingers before being able to sign Sancho. It remains unclear if the Serie A outfit will achieve this, but if they do, it's suggested that a deal for Sancho may be on the cards.

Should Sancho leave Old Trafford to move to Turin, it could allow United to reinvest some of the money earned from the transfer on a deal for Mbeumo. A lot has to happen for this to become a reality, of course, with negotiations still taking place between United and Brentford over a deal for Mbeumo.

headline: Man United bargain transfer option told to complete move 'immediately'
body: Manchester United have been told to complete a summer transfer 'immediately'.
United are in the market for a new centre forward, with it still unknown whether Ruben Amorim wishes to stick with Rasmus Hojlund.
Hojlund has made it clear in recent weeks that he wants to stay and fight for his future at Old Trafford, but the Dane scored only five Premier League goals across the whole 2024/25 campaign.
Other options at present include Joshua Zirkzee and teenage prodigy Chido Obi, although it remains unclear just how much trust Amorim has in either option to lead his forward line.
The Red Devils missed out on Liam Delap, who opted to join Chelsea, whilst fellow option Viktor Gyokeres looks to be closing in on a deal with Arsenal.
Furthermore, Victor Osimhen, Hugo Ekitike and Ollie Watkins have all also been linked, with former Everton man Moise Kean the next name to have been reported.
But it is Dusan Vlahovic who has been advised to complete a move to the Theatre of Dreams this summer, especially given the ongoing uncertainty surrounding his career in Italy with Juventus.
Vlahovic, 25, will not budge on his wage demands and does not appear to be integrating well with new manager Igor Tudor’s plans and thus causing a logjam up front.
Former Juve striker Darko Kovacevic has insisted he should seek pastures new with haste, and given talk around a move to the Premier League, his wish may come true.
"I’d say to Dušan to move on immediately," the 51-year-old told Gazzetta dello Sport.

"It’s not easy to leave Juventus, I say this from personal experience, but sometimes you have to get back in the game to get back to being happy and at the top. Someone like Vlahović must always be a starter, at Juventus or elsewhere."
Asked which club the Serbian forward would suit best, he added: "We can’t afford him at Olympiacos, but Milan and Manchester United would be good options for Dušan.
"And maybe Nottingham Forest… That’s a joke: we’re owned by the same club as the English club, but I only work for Olympiacos.”

headline: SMITH: Manchester United have four players fighting for one position after £62.5m transfer
body: Manchester United will step up their pre-season preparations when they face Leeds United in their opening friendly of the summer at the Friends Arena in Stockholm next Saturday.
The clash with Daniel Farke's men, who won promotion back to the Premier League last season, will almost certainly mark Matheus Cunha's debut in a United shirt.
The Brazilian arrived from Wolves for £62.5million last month and will be keen to enjoy a strong pre-season campaign ahead of the competitive action commencing in mid-August.
Cunha was a top target for United head coach Ruben Amorim, meaning he is poised to become a staple in his first-choice starting XI this season.

Well-versed in a 3-4-2-1 formation from his time at Molineux, Cunha is expected to occupy the left-sided No.10 position in Amorim's system. He regularly operated in that role at Wolves, meaning he should be able to settle into the groove at Old Trafford relatively comfortably.

Amid the expectation that Cunha will cement himself as United's left-sided playmaker, captain Bruno Fernandes is expected to operate in central midfield permanently this season. The Portuguese international often played as one of the two No.8s in the second half of last term and regularly looked more dangerous.
He enjoyed a real purple patch after initially being tasked with operating deeper, providing both goals and assists. Playing deeper also allows him to scan the game and help dictate proceedings.
With Fernandes expected to become a No.8 on a full-time basis, it means one of the two central midfield spots in Amorim's system is already sealed.
Therefore, Amorim will be hoping to witness some healthy competition throughout pre-season in the race to start the campaign as Fernandes' midfield partner.

United want to sign a midfielder this summer, but they are having to prioritise attacking additions instead. They are still in talks with Brentford to sign Bryan Mbeumo and they are yet to source a striker.
After finishing last season with a negative goal difference of -10 in the Premier League, United must prioritise the addition of a No.9 over a new midfielder this summer.

With that in mind, pre-season performances could dictate who starts the season as Fernandes' midfield partner. Manuel Ugarte, who was recruited from Paris Saint-Germain almost a year ago, will believe he is a worthy candidate to start, likewise fellow midfield enforcer Casemiro.

Ugarte joined United last August with the ambition of fixing their midfield problems. His debut season at the club featured a collection of up and down performances, with concerns often being shared about his ability on the ball.

As a midfield enforcer, though, he was able to flex his muscles, offering United a sense of bite and aggression in the engine room. Casemiro, on the other hand, struggled to deal with the intensity of the Premier League, saving his best performances for the Europa League.
The Brazilian could be sold this summer amid the fact his contract is up next summer. The addition of a new midfielder could spell the end of his Old Trafford career.

Kobbie Mainoo will be hoping to make up for lost time this season after a stop-start 2024/25 campaign. He struggled to get into any sort of rhythm last term because of both injuries and being tasked with operating as either a No.8 or a No.10.

In truth, Mainoo joining forces with Fernandes in midfield will leave United short of defensive nous and bite in the engine room. Mainoo is a forward-thinking player, who likes to take the ball on the half turn, glide past his man and get into attacking positions.

The only way in which Fernandes and Mainoo could potentially join forces in the middle is if United were to revert to a three-man midfield and had a defensive specialist alongside them. That, though, is not going to happen under Amorim's watch.
Toby Collyer will also believe he is worthy of an opportunity to impress in pre-season, but he will have his work cut out to try and leapfrog Ugarte, Casemiro and Mainoo in the pecking order.

Nevertheless, he will determined to prove his worth ahead of the competitive action kicking off next month. He has offered glimpses of his capabilities and will not give up on attempting to become a regular starter.
Whatever happens, a healthy level of competition can only be a good thing for Amorim.

headline: Tottenham have shown Man United how they can complete Viktor Gyokeres transfer
body: Sporting Lisbon are proving to be a difficult nut to crack as they try to receive the best possible price for their talisman, Viktor Gyokeres, this summer.

Arsenal's negotiations with the Portuguese club have nearly hit a dead end as Sporting president Frederico Varandas continues to push for a total deal priced at £69m. The issue from Gyokeres' side, which is currently resulting in the player effectively going on strike, is that he was under the impression he could leave for just under £60m.

Varandas has confirmed that Sporting will be launching disciplinary action against Gyokeres for failing to report for the start of pre-season. Such behaviour may feel uncommon practice, however Sporting do have precedent for dealing with clubs like this and Manchester United have already been told the formula to succeed.

Cast your minds back to the January transfer window of 2023 and Tottenham Hotspur seemed certain to be signing Pedro Porro from Sporting. All was agreed and a medical was booked in London for the full-back.

However, as The Athletic reported at the time, the deal was on the verge of being called off as Varandas made a last-minute ploy for more money by reneging on the offer that was already agreed. This unconventional move is not too far removed from what the Sporting president is doing with Gyokeres.

Eventually, Spurs were able to get their man through help from Porro who admitted he did not turn up to training on deadline day so that he could force Sporting's hand. United will hope the Swedish centre-forward is not having to resort to such tricks come the end of August if they are trying to sign him but the lessons from the Porro deal are a timely reminder for the Reds.
Sooner or later, Sporting are going to have to fold on Gyokeres. They simply cannot afford to have a player in their squad who is willing to not turn up to training until a move away is completed.

It makes no sense for Varandas to keep a player against his will and while, at the moment, he is happy to hold his line due to the lack of competitive fixtures, he will have no choice but to compromise as we edge closer to the regular season beginning. Should United want Gyokeres, they must remain patient and trust that negotiating with Sporting will become easier as the transfer window progresses.

headline: Manchester United transfer latest as fresh Tottenham battle emerges for £30m star
body: Manchester United's plans for the summer transfer are continuing as they look to add further new signings to their squad.

Matheus Cunha is the only new addition to Ruben Amorim's squad at United so far this summer. Brentford star Bryan Mbeumo is also a target for United as they also look to target a striker before the transfer window closes on September 1.

One area of the squad that may be in need of strengthening is the midfield, particularly following the departure of Christian Eriksen. The Denmark international left United as a free agent after his contract expired at the end of June.
United have been linked with signing a new midfielder this summer, and now a fresh rumour has emerged about a potential target.

Caught Offside have reported that Bayern Munich star Joao Palhinha is now a player of interest to United this summer. The report claims that United will face competition from Tottenham Hotspur in the race to sign the Portugal international.

Palhinha joined Bayern in the summer of 2024 from Fulham in a deal reportedly worth €56million (£48.4million). However, there are now suggestions that the midfielder could be on the way out of the Allianz Arena after just 12 months with the Bundesliga champions.

United are mentioned in the report as having already made an approach to Bayern to enquire about the possibility of signing Palhinha. The midfielder is reported to be valued at around €35million (£30.3million).
It remains to be seen if United will look to bring Palhinha to Old Trafford this summer, or if they will target a player to fill the void left by Eriksen's departure.
United were linked with signing the midfielder last year before he joined Bayern and now reports suggests their interest has been reactivated.

headline: Ex-Man Utd star decides to ‘sue’ Red Devils for ‘clinical negligence’ as ‘legal claim lodged’
body: According to reports, Manchester United are being ‘sued’ by an ex-player, who has decided to ‘lodge a legal claim’ over ‘clinical negligence’.
Just when you thought that matters could not get worse for Man Utd…

United’s issues off the pitch have had a knock-on effect on team performances, with the Premier League giants stooping to an embarrassing new low during the 2024/25 campaign despite sitting second in our net spend table.

The Red Devils were one of the worst teams in the Premier League as they were fortunate to finish 15th, while they are preparing for a season without football with a limited budget after losing to Tottenham Hotspur in the Europa League final.

Sir Jim Ratcliffe and INEOS have balanced the books since completing their takeover amid a brutal cost-cutting programme, but the situation at Old Trafford remains dour as their summer transfer window is yet to get off the ground.
READ: Man Utd: Amorim ‘frustrated’ over two ‘priority demands’ amid ‘fresh hit’ on starter unable to do ‘basics’

With the Red Devils struggling to offload their unwanted talents, including Marcus Rashford, Alejandro Garnacho, Antony and Jadon Sancho, they have only made two summer signings, landing Matheus Cunha and Diego Leon for around £65m combined.
Now, the Red Devils are faced with a legal battle involving former defender Axel Tuanzebe.
The 27-year-old progressed through the ranks at Man Utd and was touted as a future star, but he only made 37 senior appearances for his boyhood club before leaving as he was dogged by injuries.
After having loan stints at Aston Villa, Napoli and Stoke City, Tuanzebe left permanently during the 2023 summer transfer window to join Ipswich Town.
The versatile defender made 45 appearances over two seasons for Ipswich and has recently joined newly-promoted Burnley on a free transfer.
And it’s now emerged that Tuanzebe, as revealed by The Telegraph, is ‘suing’ Man Utd for ‘clinical negligence’, accusing the club of derailing his career with poor ‘medical advice’.
The report adds:
‘Telegraph Sport can reveal that the 27-year-old, who left United two years ago when his contract expired, has lodged a legal claim at the High Court.
‘Lawyers for Tuanzebe declined to comment on the action brought by a player.’
Man Utd were ‘approached for comment on the filed lawsuit’ but are yet to respond after they posted a heartfelt tribute to Tuanzebe after he left the club in 2023.

They said: “His departure is an emotional one for the player and many at the club who have known and helped nurture him over the years. A fine character, he leaves United universally respected as a credit to himself and his family.

“Everyone at the club would like to extend our best wishes to Axel as he embarks upon the next chapter of his career. We would also like to thank him for always representing Manchester United with class and dignity.”

headline: Every Premier League transfer and release confirmed in the summer of 2025
body: The Premier League transfer window opened on June 1 and then closed on June 10 for six days before re-opening on Monday June 16 until Deadline Day on Monday September 1.
Here’s what we know so far…

headline: Man Utd ‘prepare’ two bids worth £113m for next two signings after Bryan Mbeumo
body: Man Utd are ‘preparing’ to make bids for their next two targets after they wrap up a deal for Brentford forward Bryan Mbeumo, according to reports.
The Red Devils have made two signings so far this summer with Matheus Cunha joining from Wolves and youngster Diego Leon arriving from Cerro Porteno.
Given the terrible season Man Utd had last term, finishing 15th in the Premier League, the Red Devils supporters would have hoped for a few more signings through the door by mid-July.
Man Utd have been working hard to get some of the players that Ruben Amorim doesn’t want off their books with Marcus Rashford, Antony, Jadon Sancho, Alejandro Garnacho and others not wanted.
While they are also trying to agree a fee with Brentford for Mbeumo with Man Utd having two bids turned down as talks continue this week.

In an update on a deal, Romano said on his YouTube channel over the weekend: “I can guarantee to you again this week, Man United, fully focused on Bryan Mbeumo deal with Brentford, with conversations still underway, with Man United’s absolute focus being on Mbeumo, with a player still waiting for Manchester United as a top priority.
READ: Transfer rumour ranking: Man Utd to get top striker for free? Forest fuming over leak

“So they keep advancing. They keep working on this deal for Mbeumo. There is still an agreement to reach with Brentford, but I’m told that the conversations are ongoing to try to reach this agreement and let the player travel and complete his move. So Man United keep working on Bryan Mbeumo as absolute priority.”

Before he added on Sunday: “The contacts are still ongoing between United, Brentford, people involved in the deal. Mbeumo still wants to go to Manchester United, and the club maintains their confidence, their optimism, to get the green light and sign Bryan Mbeumo in the next days.

“So still no breakthrough in this story as of tonight but Manchester United keep advancing to find the right structure for the deal. They are working on easy and difficult add-ons, trying to make Brentford happy with their final proposal. So Man United are still on it. The Bryan Mbeumo deal is absolutely alive at this moment.”

And Man Utd are already lining up their next two deals too, if reports are to be believed, with Palmeiras Online claiming that the Red Devils are ‘preparing an offer’ of £26m for Richard Rios after watching the Colombian play for the Brazilian side at the Club World Cup.

Man Utd ‘sent scouts to closely monitor the midfielder’s performance at the Club World Cup’ but the ‘Palmeiras board is likely to reject the offer’ from the Red Devils as they are looking to start negotiations at around £30m.

While Spanish website Mundo Deportivo (via Sports Mole) has claimed that Man Utd have identified Barcelona youngster Marc Casado as a ‘key target’ with the Premier League side ‘preparing massive offer’ of €100m (£87m) for the midfielder.

Casado is ‘viewed as an ideal long-term alternative to Manuel Ugarte’ but the only way to sign the Spaniard is to trigger his €100m release clause as Barcelona would ‘prefer to retain’ the defensive midfielder.
Man Utd and Tottenham are among a host of clubs around Europe keeping an eye on one of the Club World Cup’s standout performers.
Premier League giants Liverpool and Chelsea have both submitted offers for Barcelona defensive midfielder Marc Casado, according to reports.
Mikel Arteta could smell opportunity as Arsenal look to exploit Barcelona’s financial crisis as the Gunners’ rebuild rolls on.
Arsenal have made a £34m ‘offer’ for the 21-year-old and are now ‘waiting for an answer’ from Barcelona, who are thought to be open to his transfer this summer.
Arsenal have ‘taken the first step’ towards signing a Barcelona star for £51m after Mikel Arteta made an ‘express request’ over the midfielder’s transfer.

headline: Man Utd: Amorim ‘frustrated’ over two ‘priority demands’ amid ‘fresh hit’ on starter unable to do ‘basics’
body: Head coach Ruben Amorim is reportedly ‘frustrated’ at how this summer transfer window is going for Manchester United after making two ‘priority demands’.
This is Amorim‘s first summer transfer window as Man Utd boss and it is not going to plan for the head coach.
The Red Devils require a massive squad overhaul as their dire 2024/25 campaign proved that most of their players are not good enough and need to be replaced.

Amorim may regret his decision to join Man Utd mid-season as his unsuited squad struggled to adapt to his preferred 3-4-3 formation as they plummeted to 15th in the Premier League and lost in the Europa League final.

A win over Spurs in the Europa League final would have been a huge boost as it would have secured Champions League football and a huge injection of cash, but the defeat leaves them with a limited budget and sales are required to raise funds.
READ: Man Utd ‘agree terms’ for ‘very close major’ third signing as ‘approval granted’ amid ‘compromise’
But with United yet to offload any of their pricey outcasts, Matheus Cunha and Diego Leon are their only summer signings.
Man Utd really ought to get a wriggle on as they still have loads of business to do, but a fresh report has claimed that club chiefs face paying ‘millions’ to get three players off their books.
It is clearly a mess and a report from Flashscore claims Amorim is ‘frustrated’ amid United’s ‘struggle in the transfer market’.

It is also noted that he was ‘clear about two transfer priorities for Manchester United at the end of last season’, as he ‘demanded a proven goalscorer to address the lack of firepower in attack and also wanted a reliable goalkeeper who could be trusted in key moments’.

It is claimed that ‘Amorim still does not have the profile of striker he asked for’ after he ‘pushed for Victor Osimhen or Viktor Gyokeres as he wanted a No. 9 with presence, pedigree, and consistency’.
And while it is also pointed out that there is ‘internal frustration that no attackers have been moved on’, the goalkeeper situation has ‘taken a fresh hit’.
The report claims:

‘While there is no personal issue between Amorim and Onana, it is understood that the boss had grown frustrated with the goalkeeper’s inability to consistently execute the basics. He wants to build from the back with confidence and that has not been possible.

‘United were open to offers for Onana in the window, and although there were conversations with intermediaries, no concrete bids have arrived. Onana’s camp made it known that he was not actively seeking a move, and that has complicated matters further. Ideally, Amorim would have replaced him, but if not, the plan was always to bring in a goalkeeper to compete with Onana. That remains the case.’
According to reports, head coach Ruben Amorim has set a clear ‘deadline’ for Manchester United to complete their third summer signing.
Man Utd could have a chance of signing Emiliano Martinez this summer as Aston Villa prepare to announce a new goalkeeper signing, according to reports.
Manchester United are reportedly ‘weighing up’ a ‘reunion’ for one of Ruben Amorim’s former Sporting CP stars, as it’s felt they will ‘listen to offers’.
That an access-all-areas documentary about Man Utd next season was given the consideration it was shows again the size of the job before Ruben Amorim…
Andre Onana only joined Untied two years ago but already looks to be heading out the door if the club get their way.
Why are giving Manchester United boss Ruben Amorim excuses to be terrible? Plus, more on Spurs, Arsenal and Diogo Jota.

headline: Fabrizio Romano rules out Man Utd ‘hijack’ of £65m striker deal: ‘This is not true’
body: Transfer expert Fabrizio Romano has ruled out a move from Man Utd to “hijack” Galatasaray’s deal for Napoli striker Victor Osimhen.
The Red Devils have only made one major signing this summer with Matheus Cunha joining from Wolves in a deal worth £62.5m, while youngster Diego Leon also arrived from Cerro Porteno.
Man Utd have also been bidding for Brentford forward Bryan Mbeumo but the Bees are holding firm on their £70m valuation of the player.

In an update over the weekend, Romano said of the Red Devils’ chase for Mbeumo: “I can guarantee to you again this week, Man United, fully focused on Bryan Mbeumo deal with Brentford, with conversations still underway, with Man United’s absolute focus being on Mbeumo, with a player still waiting for Manchester United as a top priority.

“So they keep advancing. They keep working on this deal for Mbeumo. There is still an agreement to reach with Brentford, but I’m told that the conversations are ongoing to try to reach this agreement and let the player travel and complete his move. So Man United keep working on Bryan Mbeumo as absolute priority.”
Man Utd are also keen to bring in a new centre-forward this summer with numerous names linked, including Sporting CP’s Viktor Gyokeres, who is on the verge of signing for Arsenal.
READ: Transfer rumour ranking: Man Utd to get top striker for free? Forest fuming over leak

Napoli striker Osimhen – who spent last season on loan at Turkish giants Galatasaray – is available this summer with Man Utd heavily linked to the Nigeria international, as well as other Premier League sides.

It now looks almost certain that Osimhen will join up with Galatasaray on a permanent basis this summer despite a report in recent days that Man Utd could still look to hijack a deal worth €75m (£65m).

Responding to rumours of a potential Man Utd hijack, Romano revealed on his YouTube channel: “Reports about Man Utd hijacking the deal of Galatasaray from Victor Osimhen, from what I’m told, this is not true.
“Osimhen is getting closer to joining Galatasaray. €75m deal. Now, Napoli have to give final approval. Galatasaray are getting closer after always being confident about signing Osimhen.
“New contacts will take place in the new week. Man Utd are not part of this story, not part of this conversation, also because Galatasaray will give Osimhen an important salary – €16m/season.
“Man Utd were never going to be at the table for those numbers in terms of salary. Forget about the hijack.”
According to reports, Arsenal have reached a ‘verbal agreement’ for another signing, with Fabrizio Romano claiming a ‘medical’ could soon take place.
Viktor Gyokeres’ agents have ‘landed in London’ as they look to seal the final details of a move to Arsenal, according to Fabrizio Romano.
Man Utd are racing Everton to the signing of Leicester City midfielder Wilfred Ndidi in a potential £9m deal, according to reports.
Transfer expert Fabrizio Romano insists there is “nothing at this stage” between Tottenham defender Cristian Romero and Atletico Madrid.
Manchester United are reportedly targeting three central midfielders as their ‘next priority’ if and when they finally complete a deal for Bryan Mbeumo.
Arsenal have announced that they have completed their third summer signing, while Fabrizio Romano has confirmed that another transfer is “absolutely on”.

headline: Transfer rumour ranking: Bayern turn to Arsenal star as Liverpool discuss West Ham deal
body: Liverpool’s reluctance to sell Luis Diaz could see Bayern Munich raid Arsenal instead, while West Ham are exploring a deal for a Reds talent…
With so much transfer talk doing the rounds, we’re here through the summer to sift through the bullsh*t and highlight the whispers that might have some substance.
Each day we’re ranking the top 20 rumours involving Premier League clubs, the higher the link, the more likely we feel they are to become done deals.
So we start with the tittle-tattle…

20) Luis Diaz – Liverpool to Bayern Munich
Reports over the weekend suggested Bayern had made a £45million bid for a player who seems quite keen to move. But Liverpool are either serious when they say he’s not for sale, or they’re intent on driving the hardest of bargains.

MORE ON THE SUMMER 2025 TRANSFER WINDOW
👉 Every Premier League transfer and release confirmed in the summer of 2025
👉 Twenty biggest transfers in the world in 2025 summer transfer window

19) Jadon Sancho – Manchester United to Juventus
There has been speculation that Juve preferred a permanent move for Francisco Conceicao but the Porto winger’s release clause is about to go up by 50%, so we ought to see some clarity soon if Juve are serious about Sancho. And, perhaps more importantly, how serious Sancho is about Juve and kickstarting his tail-spinning career.

18) Dusan Vlahovic – Juventus to Manchester United
Juve’s problem here is similar to United’s with Sancho: they owe the player another year of a huge salary. But Vlahovic may be prepared to forego it if Juve simply cut him loose and allow him to find a contract elsewhere as a free-agent. Which would certainly suit United. But reports suggest Milan might be a problem for the Red Devils.

17) Marc Guehi – Crystal Palace to Liverpool
With a year left on his contract and a renewal unlikely, Palace are willing to cash in on their captain – but Liverpool won’t pay the £50million or so the Eagles are demanding. Currently, we are at stalemate. Liverpool don’t seem twitchy yet, but they are keeping the lines of communication open.

16) 🆕 Leandro Trossard – Arsenal to Bayern Munich
With Arsenal looking to sign players in the positions Trossard plays, it makes sense that they cash in on the attacker. Who just so happened to change his representatives this summer to a fella well connected with the German big-hitters. Trossard has two years remaining on his contract and would be around half the price of Diaz.

15) 🆕 Harvey Elliott – Liverpool to West Ham
The Hammers seem keen to put some of their Kudus cash into luring Elliott away from Liverpool but it is so far unclear what the Reds would accept. The Guardian says ‘preparations for a move are being conducted’ which have to start with a simple question: how much?

14) Eberechi Eze – Crystal Palace to Arsenal
Eze is keen on the prospect of moving to the Emirates and some reports suggest a deal is now down to the finer details of how the fee to activate his release clause is paid. Arsenal are a little tied up this week with Madueke and Gyokeres, but once those deals are done, we can expect some progress over Eze.

13) Marcus Rashford – Manchester United to Barcelona
With Nico Williams signing a new contract with Athletic Bilbao and Liverpool ignoring interest in Luis Diaz, Rashford is said to have found himself at the top of Barca’s wish-list and the Catalans are ready to go ‘all in’. Unfortunately for Barca – and United – ‘all’ doesn’t amount to much these days. Rashford wants the move and, most likely, United will be paying him to play as a loanee at the Nou Camp next season.

12) 🔼 Cristhian Mosquera – Valencia to Arsenal
Arsenal had one bid rejected for the 2024 Golden Boy-shortlisted defender but they remain in talks with Valencia. Which didn’t appear to be going well, but Ornstein suggests the Gunners are getting there.

11) 🔽 Darwin Nunez – Liverpool to Napoli
Napoli were ready to pay £43million plus about £4.4million for Nunez, who could yet be offered £100k a week after tax, which represents a slight raise on what he trousers at Anfield. But reports over the weekend suggest the Serie A champions have backed away somewhat, preferring instead a £30million deal for Udinese’s Lorenzo Lucca. It could all be part of the transfer dance if Napoli are looking for a sweeter deal from Liverpool, but this certainly doesn;t appear as advanced as it did last week.

10) Bryan Mbeumo – Brentford to Manchester United
United remain in talks with Brentford and they are, apparently, hopeful of getting a deal done before the end of the week. We’ve heard that once, probably twice, already. United fly off to the United States in a week and Ruben Amorim wants Mbeumo on board.

9) James Trafford – Burnley to Newcastle
This has been going on for over a year but Newcastle are likely to get this done – finally – once the two clubs stop faffing and agree on all the T&Cs around a £30million deal.

8) 🔼 Evan Ferguson – Brighton to Roma
After a loan spell at West Ham in which he did absolutely nothing, Ferguson is now close to joining Roma on loan, with some claiming the Italians will retain the option to buy. Sounds like a great opportunity for a striker once rated at £100million to kickstart his stalling career, assuming the two clubs can find an agreement over a fee should the loan become a permanent arrangement.

6) Mark Travers – Bournemouth to Everton
Travers is heading to Merseyside as he prepares to swap the Bournemouth bench for Everton’s new one. Once his medical is wrapped up later today, the Toffees will complete a deal worth £4million plus add-ons. Which we assume won’t be heavily incentivised on playing time.

5) 🔼 Marco Bizot – Brest to Aston Villa
The once-capped Netherlands international keeper is in Birmingham to complete a move to Villa. We assume to serve as Emi Martinez’s understudy but it remains possible the Argentina World Cup winner could be on his way before the end of the window.

4) 🔼 Djordje Petrovic – Chelsea to Bournemouth
Bournemouth have agreed to take another Chelsea keeper, this time permanently, with the 25-year-old moving for £25million. Petrovic will have a medical once Chelsea fly back from the United States.

3) 🔼 Viktor Gyokeres – Sporting to Arsenal
So many claims and counter claims now, we had almost given up trying to keep up. But this seems to be reaching what felt like the inevitable conclusion amid reports a deal has finally been agreed between the two clubs. Indeed, Gyokeres’ representatives are in London now though a five-year contract was agreed weeks ago.

2) Jordan Henderson – Ajax to Brentford
No romantic return to Sunderland, who are a bit busy signing everyone else, Henderson is close to signing for Brentford to replace Arsenal new boy Christian Norgaard. Thomas Tuchel will be chuffed, and so will Arne Slot, since Henderson will probably refuse to tackle any Liverpool player out of #respect.

1) 🔼 Noni Madueke – Chelsea to Arsenal
The Chelsea winger is at Arsenal today to wrap up a medical and the final details of a £52million move. Which will prompt some screeching U-turns among the Arsenal fan base, you would expect.

headline: Pre-season money jaunts killing the planet and the players
body: It’s money month, the time of year when the season sort of starts again with friendlies and fake tournaments, but not really. It’s also a despicable time when the ugliness of top-flight football arrogantly bestrides the world in pursuit of tiny amounts of extra money.
If your side does well, it cheers you for the new campaign; a few poor results and everyone is disgruntled. And it usually proves no guide to what happens in the season.

ITV even showed Preston v Liverpool. It still seemed more significant than the CWC obviously, but I seriously wonder about the fitness of footballers who last played internationals a month ago. We’re familiar with player burn-out as a concept, though it’s usually only used as an excuse for defeat, not a reason for victory. You’ve been playing for the best part of 11 months; you’re not going to lose anything in a month that a friendly against Preston would revive. Surely light training is all that’s needed.

Back in the day, the time off would last from mid-May until mid-August, a time which would be spent drinking and eating gravy dinners, so players would need to run up sand dunes – vomiting as Big Jack shouted profanities – to get fit again, but I doubt that’s the case now that they measure everything all the time and they live off chicken and pasta.

I watched Middlesbrough play and lose to Port Clarence Reserves in the 70s, but clubs have now realised there’s money in pre-season games and pretending they’re competitive. So this Saturday you could watch Gateshead v Sunderland or Matlock v Derby or Dartford v Charlton amongst others. I’m not sure anyone except the most loyal obsessive bothered, but it’s a part of a great tradition. And of course bigger clubs are playing in fake tournaments all across the world so they can earn enough to pay for a reserve full-back from Austria.

But then Premier League clubs are different, moral-free beasts with no conscience. The Guardian reckons the 20 clubs are unconscionably taking a planet-breaking 175,000 summer air miles in just a few weeks, the idiots. Manchester United are flying 24,000 miles to show off their mediocrity and are even playing Leeds in Stockholm. City are spending 15,000 miles in the air and face Palermo in Sicily to contest the inaugural Anglo Palermitan Trophy which commemorates the Sicilian club’s maiden fixture against a team of British sailors in 1900. At least they’re used to wasting energy competing in insignificant tournaments. You’re playing for fans in the country you’re flying to, are you? As they die in the heat or are swept away in floods, I’m sure they’ll appreciate it..

Time was they’d play a relatively near lower-league side to help them earn much-needed money from the gate receipts for games that were much in demand. Games like the one v Preston are rare. You can see Liverpool play Milan in Hong Kong though. Or Newcastle play Arsenal in Singapore. No game against Blyth Spartans in Blyth, then? Nah, that’s just legacy thinking.
Personally I loved the pre-season friendly. Boro went through a phase of playing Hibs thanks to Tony Mowbray’s connections and they were always great pish-ups that Hibs certainly took seriously.

There is a better solution, though it would deny these clubs money to fritter away. Scottish football, which I know most of you don’t care about, and to be fair does have the tradition of terrible decisions by the SFA, got it right for once and has had a much better idea with the Premier Sports Cup. The group stage involves 40 clubs – the 37 SPFL clubs for 2025/26 who are not involved in European competition plus Bonnyrigg Rose (relegated to Lowland League), Brora Rangers (Highland League winners) and Brechin City (Highland League runners-up).

Teams are drawn into eight groups of five based on final league positions in 2024/25 and it fires the starting gun on the new season this weekend. They realised that the League Cup retains some credibility so they set up a league stage, where they get to play actual competitive games instead of friendlies and football-starved fans lap it up in the ‘foreign’ July heat, heading towards a final in December.

It is often the one trophy that the Glasgow big two don’t actually always win, though Celtic are the current holders and it has value because of that alone. The CWC has shown the pointlessness of playing in tournaments no one believes in.

Why doesn’t England swallow its ego and copy Scotland instead of treating it like a poor, pish-stinking old relation? It’d get the competition done earlier, providing an early meaningful start to the season. They’re obviously not opposed to playing in July. However, the gate receipts are probably dwarfed by money gained playing in these fake overseas tournaments. So once again, we see how local, domestic football suffers because of the insatiable lust for money, no matter how small, in a way it once never was.

Pre-season pulls back the curtain and shows the most important thing to top clubs. It’s not football or even fitness. It’s just money. Nothing else. The hateful club execs, desperate to justify their lavish wages, just care about money. 175,000 miles. Climate change doesn’t discriminate in favour of football clubs, y’now. You die too. Good luck paying to offset that. And more to the point, you’re effectively killing and ruining the lives of your own fans. Yeah, that makes good economic, if not moral, sense.

Even that doesn’t stop the stupids or deniers. More money, more money, more money. Stop buying players! We’d rather see a local kid come through. No? They’re all crap? Well, that’s down to you. But you’d rather fry in 33 degrees of heat to get one place higher in the league? Morons. It’s 27 degrees here on the west coast of Scotland, it’s unnatural. And when you get skin cancer you can thank the Premier League for not giving a shit and putting a few quid above the health of the planet and its people. F*cking idiots.

So craven for a little bit more money, they are even prepared to exploit not just the Earth but their own assets to the maximum and then some, even at the risk of breaking those same assets, the way they’re breaking the planet. To a rational mind it makes zero sense and is the economics of the madhouse. Protest this obscene situation because they are willingly blind to it. On the contrary, they think they’re clever.

Further down the pyramid, it’s still as it ever was as your local centre-half takes a break from laying bricks to kick your fancy striker up in the air, but it’d be nice if it actually mattered and since they’re already playing, why not? Keep pre-season local.
Does the environment not matter? Obviously not. What a terrible example to future generations who will have to live with and combat their selfishness, if they live at all.
